metadata.title: Angles and Pairs of Angles
metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.description: Adjacent angles, complementary, supplementary, linear pair, vertically opposite angles

preAssessment.question: Two angles whose sum is 90Â° are called _____.
Two angles whose sum is 180Â° are called _____.
What is the complement of a 40Â° angle?
When two lines intersect, vertically opposite angles are _____.
The sum of interior angles of a pentagon is _____.

concepts.title: Adjacent Angles
concepts.content: Two angles which have a common vertex, a common arm and separate interiors are said to be adjacent angles. They are like neighbouring angles that share a side but don't overlap. The common arm lies between the two angles.

examples.text: âˆ BMQ and âˆ QMD share vertex M and arm MQ
A door partly open forms adjacent angles with the wall
Clock hands at 3 o'clock form adjacent angles
Scissors open form two adjacent angles

keyPoints: Adjacent angles have one common arm
They have a common vertex
Their interiors are separate (don't overlap)
The other arms lie on opposite sides of the common arm
If interiors are not separate, they are NOT adjacent angles
concepts.funFact: ğŸ“ The word 'adjacent' comes from Latin meaning 'lying near' â€” adjacent angles literally lie next to each other!

concepts.title: Complementary Angles
concepts.content: If the sum of the measures of two angles is 90Â°, they are called complementary angles. Each angle is the complement of the other. For example, 40Â° and 50Â° are complementary since 40Â° + 50Â° = 90Â°.

examples.text: 40Â° and 50Â° are complementary: 40+50=90Â°
Complement of 70Â° = 90Â° - 70Â° = 20Â°
If angles are (a+15)Â° and (2a)Â°: a+15+2a=90 â†’ a=25 â†’ angles are 40Â° and 50Â°
In a right-angled triangle, the two acute angles are complementary

keyPoints: Sum of complementary angles = 90Â°
Each is the complement of the other
Complement of xÂ° = (90 - x)Â°
Two right angles CANNOT be complementary
Complementary angles need not be adjacent
concepts.funFact: ğŸ’¡ In any right-angled triangle, the two non-right angles are always complementary to each other!

concepts.title: Supplementary Angles
concepts.content: If the sum of the measures of two angles is 180Â°, they are called supplementary angles. Each is the supplement of the other. For example, 110Â° and 70Â° are supplementary since 110Â° + 70Â° = 180Â°.

examples.text: 135Â° and 45Â° are supplementary: 135+45=180Â°
Supplement of 135Â° = 180Â° - 135Â° = 45Â°
(a+30)Â° and (2a)Â° supplementary: a+30+2a=180 â†’ a=50 â†’ 80Â° and 100Â°
A straight line forms a 180Â° angle â€” any ray on it creates supplementary angles

keyPoints: Sum of supplementary angles = 180Â°
Supplement of xÂ° = (180 - x)Â°
Two right angles (90Â°+90Â°) are supplementary
One acute + one obtuse angle can be supplementary
Two obtuse angles CANNOT be supplementary
concepts.funFact: ğŸ  The two angles that a staircase railing makes with the floor and ceiling are supplementary angles!

concepts.title: Linear Pair and Opposite Rays
concepts.content: Two rays with a common origin that form a straight line are called opposite rays. Angles which have a common arm and whose other arms form a straight line are angles in a linear pair. The sum of angles in a linear pair is always 180Â°.

examples.text: Ray BC and ray BA in a straight line are opposite rays
âˆ PQR and âˆ RQS form a linear pair: sum = 180Â°
A candle flame: rays going up and down are opposite rays
A road going left and right from an intersection

keyPoints: Opposite rays: common origin, form a straight line
Linear pair: adjacent angles whose non-common arms form a straight line
Sum of angles in a linear pair = 180Â°
Angles in a linear pair are supplementary
Linear pair angles are always adjacent
concepts.funFact: ğŸ¯ A linear pair always sums to 180Â° â€” that's why a straight line is also called a 180Â° angle!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 28-29: Opposite Rays and Linear Pair

concepts.title: Vertically Opposite Angles and Polygon Angles
concepts.content: When two lines intersect, the opposite angles formed are equal â€” these are vertically opposite angles. The sum of interior angles of a polygon with n sides = 180Â° Ã— (n-2). The exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of its two remote interior angles.

examples.text: Lines PT and RS intersect at Q: âˆ PQR = âˆ SQT (vertically opposite)
Pentagon (5 sides): 180Â°Ã—(5-2) = 180Â°Ã—3 = 540Â°
Hexagon (6 sides): 180Â°Ã—(6-2) = 720Â°
Exterior angle of triangle = sum of two remote interior angles

keyPoints: Vertically opposite angles are equal
Sum of interior angles of polygon = 180Â°Ã—(n-2)
Triangle: 180Â°, Quadrilateral: 360Â°, Pentagon: 540Â°, Hexagon: 720Â°
Exterior angle of triangle = sum of two non-adjacent interior angles
Every triangle has 6 exterior angles
concepts.funFact: ğŸŒŸ The sum of interior angles formula 180Â°Ã—(n-2) works for ANY polygon â€” from triangles to hundred-sided shapes!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 29-32: Vertically Opposite Angles and Polygon Interior Angles

test.question: The complement of a 63Â° angle is _____.
The supplement of a 120Â° angle is _____.
Two angles in a linear pair sum to _____.
test.explanation: Angles in a linear pair are supplementary, so their sum is 180Â°.

test.question: Lines AC and BD intersect at P. If mâˆ APD = 47Â°, what is mâˆ BPC?
test.explanation: âˆ APD and âˆ BPC are vertically opposite angles, so they are equal: 47Â°.

test.question: The sum of interior angles of a hexagon is _____.
If âˆ ACD is an exterior angle of â–³ABC and mâˆ ACD = 140Â°, and âˆ A = âˆ B, what is mâˆ A?
test.explanation: Exterior angle = sum of remote interior angles. 140Â° = âˆ A + âˆ B = 2âˆ A â†’ âˆ A = 70Â°

test.question: Two acute angles can form a pair of supplementary angles.
test.explanation: Two acute angles each measure less than 90Â°. Their sum is less than 180Â°, so they cannot be supplementary.

test.question: What is the supplement of the complement of a 70Â° angle?
Two angles of measures (a+30)Â° and (2a)Â° are supplementary. What are the measures?
test.explanation: a+30+2a=180 â†’ 3a=150 â†’ a=50 â†’ angles are 80Â° and 100Â°

keyConcepts: Adjacent angles: common vertex, common arm, separate interiors
Linear pair: adjacent angles forming a straight line, sum = 180Â°
Sum of interior angles of n-sided polygon = 180Â°Ã—(n-2)
Exterior angle of triangle = sum of two remote interior angles
commonMisconceptions: Complementary and supplementary are the same â€” FALSE (90Â° vs 180Â°)
Adjacent angles must be complementary or supplementary â€” FALSE
Vertically opposite means they look like a V â€” FALSE, they are opposite at intersection
Two obtuse angles can be supplementary â€” FALSE (sum would exceed 180Â°)
realWorldExamples: Clock hands forming different types of angle pairs
Staircase railing making supplementary angles with floor
Road intersections creating vertically opposite angles
Architectural designs using polygon angle properties

formulas.formula: Exterior angle = sum of remote interior angles
formulas.explanation: Property of exterior angle of triangle

interactiveElement.title: Build the Formula!
interactiveElement.description: Arrange the pieces to form the correct mathematical expression.

data.formula: Sum of angles in a triangle = 180Â°
data.explanation: The three interior angles of any triangle always add up to 180 degrees.

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: The complement of a 63Â° angle is _____.
The supplement of a 120Â° angle is _____.
Two angles in a linear pair sum to _____.
qaCards.answer: Angles in a linear pair are supplementary, so their sum is 180Â°.

qaCards.question: Lines AC and BD intersect at P. If mâˆ APD = 47Â°, what is mâˆ BPC?
qaCards.answer: âˆ APD and âˆ BPC are vertically opposite angles, so they are equal: 47Â°.

qaCards.question: The sum of interior angles of a hexagon is _____.
If âˆ ACD is an exterior angle of â–³ABC and mâˆ ACD = 140Â°, and âˆ A = âˆ B, what is mâˆ A?
qaCards.answer: Exterior angle = sum of remote interior angles. 140Â° = âˆ A + âˆ B = 2âˆ A â†’ âˆ A = 70Â°

qaCards.question: Two acute angles can form a pair of supplementary angles.
qaCards.answer: Two acute angles each measure less than 90Â°. Their sum is less than 180Â°, so they cannot be supplementary.

qaCards.question: What is the supplement of the complement of a 70Â° angle?
Two angles of measures (a+30)Â° and (2a)Â° are supplementary. What are the measures?
qaCards.answer: a+30+2a=180 â†’ 3a=150 â†’ a=50 â†’ angles are 80Â° and 100Â°

longAnswers.question: Explain what is meant by the interior and exterior of an angle.
longAnswers.answer: The interior of an angle consists of the group of points in the plane that lie between the arms of the angle but are not on the arms themselves. The exterior of an angle consists of the group of points in the plane that are neither on the arms of the angle nor in its interior. This effectively categorizes the plane into three distinct parts: the interior, the exterior, and the points on the angle itself.
keyPoints: Interior points are inside the angle and not on the arms.
Exterior points are outside the angle and not on the arms.
Points can also lie exactly on the arms of the angle.

longAnswers.question: Define adjacent angles and list the necessary conditions for two angles to be adjacent.
longAnswers.answer: Two angles are said to be adjacent angles if they are neighbouring angles that share specific geometric properties. For two angles to be adjacent, they must have a common vertex and they must have exactly one common arm. Most importantly, their interiors must be completely separate, meaning they do not share a single common point within their interior spaces.
keyPoints: Adjacent angles must have a common vertex.
They must share exactly one common arm.
They must have completely separate interiors.

longAnswers.question: Why are two angles with a common arm and a common vertex not always considered adjacent angles?
longAnswers.answer: Two angles that share a common arm and a common vertex might still not be adjacent if their interiors overlap. For angles to be adjacent, they must have strictly separate interiors without any common points. If one angle is partially or completely inside the other, their interiors overlap, which disqualifies them from being adjacent angles despite sharing a vertex and an arm.
keyPoints: Adjacent angles require completely separate interiors.
Sharing a common arm and vertex is necessary but not sufficient.
Overlapping interiors disqualify angles from being adjacent.

longAnswers.question: What are complementary angles? Provide an example of how they can be formed.
longAnswers.answer: Complementary angles are defined as any two angles whose measures add up exactly to 90 degrees. When the sum of the measures of two angles is 90Â°, they are known as mutually complementary angles. For example, if you draw a 90Â° right angle and then draw a ray anywhere in its interior, the two newly formed adjacent angles will have measures that sum to exactly 90Â°, making them complementary.
keyPoints: The sum of the measures of complementary angles is exactly 90Â°.
Angles whose sum is 90Â° are mutually complementary.
A right angle divided by an interior ray forms two complementary angles.

longAnswers.question: How do you categorize the different points in the plane of an angle?
longAnswers.answer: Points in the plane of an angle can be categorized into three distinct groups based on their position relative to the angle. First, there are points that lie exactly on the arms of the angle itself forming the boundary. Second, there are points that fall in the interior of the angle, meaning they are in the space enclosed between the arms. Finally, there are points that fall in the exterior of the angle, which are neither on the arms nor in the interior.
keyPoints: Points can lie exactly on the arms of the angle.
Points can lie in the interior of the angle.
Points can lie in the exterior of the angle.
